description:
Elaeis guineensis, commonly known as the African oil palm or West African oil palm, is a species of palm tree that is native to West Africa. It is a monocotyledonous, perennial, and tropical plant species that belongs to the Arecaceae family.

The Elaeis guineensis is a large, single-stemmed tree that can grow up to 20 meters tall. It has pinnately compound leaves that can reach up to 5 meters in length, with leaflets that are dark green in color. The tree produces bunches of orange-red fruits, which are the main source of palm oil, a widely used vegetable oil.

The species is adapted to grow in warm and humid climates, typically in areas with an average annual rainfall of 1,500 to 2,000 millimeters. It thrives in well-drained, fertile soils and can tolerate a wide range of soil types, including clay, loam, and sandy soils.

Elaeis guineensis is an economically important crop, as its oil is used in a variety of products, including food, cosmetics, and biofuels. It is also an important source of income for many communities in West Africa, where it has been cultivated for centuries.
